snippet: Rory Staunton, 12, went to the emergency room with a sick stomach and fever one day in March; he was sent home, and three days later, he died of septic shock.
abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column on the death of 12-year-old Rory Staunton from sepsis after cutting his arm while playing; doctors who treated him at NYU Langone Medical Center did not access, or dismissed, critical information that would have alerted them to the life-threatening condition; a campaign to aggressively identify sepsis for early treatment has been undertaken by a consortium of 55 hospitals in the New York region, including NYU Langone, yet no one at the center acted on strong indications that the child was fighting for his life.
lead_paragraph: Rory Staunton, 12, went to the emergency room with a sick stomach and fever one day in March; he was sent home, and three days later, he died of septic shock.

headline.seo: In Rory Staunton’s Fight for His Life, Signs That Went Unheeded

keywords.value: New York University Langone Medical Center
keywords.name: organizations
